channel.title: Diode CPU
channel.description:
So... I'm thinking, if you can make a basic transistor out of two diodes, why not use the transistors made of diodes to make a basic CPU! I got the idea when I was reading some awesome magazines from the 70's when I saw an artical on transistors and this [url=http://www.instructables.com/id/TOD-Diode-Matrix-ROM-intro-7-segment-display/]here[/url]
Heres the diagramof the diodes:
[img]http://img172.imageshack.us/img172/3839/diodetransistor.png[/img]
<3 paint
So what do you think? I might scap the relay cpu (to much money) and I think this would be more fun as I want to make a fully functioning cpu eventually (to hard with relays!)

item.title: Diode CPU
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

That’s what I’d like to do but in a basic way. At the moment it’s just an idea and I havnt looked into it enough to start planning.

Read full topic

item.title: Diode CPU
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

A led is a diode, it just makes light when it conducts.
Btw, a relay CPU would be hugely power hungry dure to the power needed to energise the contacts.
But overall I think this is a moronic idea, cpu’s utilise millions of transistors, they’re not just used for basic operations such as anding values, you need to have your whole system synchronised so that data isn’t skipped or missed, you need parity bits for all data so that you don’t accidentally fuck something up, you need LOTS of error checking so that your system can stand interference from external sources (such as noise from mains or other equipment being used). You also need to make sure that after each logical operation your binary values are still within “acceptable” range so that the next operation can actually process the data, this means you’ll ideally need to find the docs for a logic family, or create your own (I’d recommend CMOS btw).
But if you can pull all that off, I will be pretty impressed.

Read full topic
